title: Lough Hyne Loop Walk Route

images.title: Martin Southwood / Bullock Island and Loch Hyne entrance
images.caption: Bullock Island and Loch Hyne entrance. Castle Island is located in the center of the lake where the ruins of Cloghan Castle, once a fortress of the O'Driscoll clan, are still visible.

images.title: Lough Hyne by nmtoken, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Lough Hyne from above

images.title: Andy Stephenson / Lough Ine
images.caption: A very interesting land-locked sea lough near Baltimore. Made famous by Trevor Norton in his book "Reflections on a Summer Sea".

images.title: Coffin stone - Knockeencon Townland by Mac McCarron, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Coffin stone - Knockeencon Townland

description: This circular walk visits the Marine Nature Reserve at Lough Hyne in West Cork near Skibbereen. The walk runs for about 8km, following trails along the western side of the lough before returning on alternative tracks just to the west of the water. You can start and end the walk from the car park at the northern end of the lough near Knockomagh Wood and the Lough Hyne Forest. Just to the north of the car park there's the Knockomagh Summit if you would like to extend your hike. From here there are fantastic views back down to the lough, over to Baltimore, Sherkin Island and the open Atlantic sea. If you were to head into nearby Skibbereen you could visit the Heritage Centre and find out more about the lough's features and biodiversity. These include environments such as cliffs, salt marsh and beach which are the subject of continual study.
